column1:
## Reason for admission
46 years old man who came in on the 2024-02-19 after referral from primary care doctor where he seeked medical attention for abdominal pain in past 5 days, constpation for 4 days and vomiting.

## Medical history
Appendectomy as a child. Hypothyroidism. Admitted to the gastroenterological ward earlier in January due to abdominal pain. Biopsy showed chronic ileitis in January.

## Hospital course
Patient had sever abdominal pain. VAS 4-7. LPK 8,9. CRP 49. No fever. Liverenzymes and amylas within reference. On examination pain when palpated in the lower abdomen, more prominently in the right fossa. No other findings in physical examination. ECG with SR, No signs of ischemia. CT of abdomen with signs of ileitis in terminal ileum. Admitted to the gastroenterological ward because of signs of terminal ileitis. Not fully recovered since discharge from the hospital in January. Worsening of abdominal pain 6 days ago and troubles eating due to nausea and vomiting. Gastroscopy done to exclude Chrons or celiac disease according to gastroeneterologists recommendations. Shows duodenopathy. Biopsy taken (celiac disease) and Helicobacter test. Initially 0 per os and received 1000 ml Ringer-Acetate and after that 1000 ml glucose with sodium and potassium. Culture from stool recommended but not taken in the ward. Antibodies for transglutaminase taken. Patient gets better, less abdominal pain and wished to go home. CRP down to 29. 

## Medications
- Alvedon (Paracetamol) 500 mg 2+0+0
- Ringer-Acetate (Ringer-Acetate) 1000 Ml 0+0+0
- Glucose 5% 40 Na 20 K 1000 Ml 0+0+0
- Oxynorm (Oxikodon) 5 mg 1+0+0
- Midazolam (Midazolam) 1 mg 1+0+0
- Alfentanil (Alfentanil) 0.5 mg 0,7+0+0

## Plan after discharge
Patient is referred to the gastroenterological outpatient clinic for a follow-up.

## Procedures
 UJD05 Gastroscopy 

## Secondary diagnosis
- Abdominal pain
- Constipation
- Hypothyroidism

## Main diagnosis
R104X Abdominal pain

## Differential diagnosis
- Chrons
- Celiac disease 
- Gastroenteritis
